title-group.article-title: Tillich's Method of Correlation: Two Proposed Revisions

ref.mixed-citation:
Reinhold Niebuhr, in his debate of many years with Tillich, writes: "My point is simply that when we deal with aspects of reality which exhibit a freedom above and beyond structures, we must resort to the Hebraic dramatic and historical way of apprehending reality. Both the divine and the human self belong to this category" (Reinhold Niebuhr: His Religious, Social, and Political Thought, ed. Charles W. Kegley and Robert W. Bretall [New York: Macmillan Co., 1961], p. 433)
Niebuhr
My point is simply that when we deal with aspects of reality which exhibit a freedom above and beyond structures, we must resort to the Hebraic dramatic and historical way of apprehending reality. Both the divine and the human self belong to this category 433 Reinhold Niebuhr: His Religious, Social, and Political Thought 1961

Tillich states his position in terms of that formulation: "Ontological analysis is just as open for the element of freedom as it is for that of destiny, for the characteristics of per- sonality and history as well as for those of life and nature" (The Theology of Paul Tillich, ed. Charles W. Kegley and Robert W. Bretall [New York: Macmillan Co., 1961], p. 338)
Tillich
Ontological analysis is just as open for the element of freedom as it is for that of destiny, for the characteristics of personality and history as well as for those of life and nature 338 The Theology of Paul Tillich 1961
